item.title: Ticket #7149 (prevent inadvertent output from included files) updated
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description:
I think this is an interesting idea, but I'd say that it might be worth expanding the idea to prevent *all* output prior to the actual theme files being called.

In other words, ob_start in the root index.php, then ob_end_clean in the template-loader.php.

I don't think this will impact cookies and headers and such, but some testing would need to be done there.

item.title: Ticket #7147 (Problems with 700+ categories) updated

Replying to ryan:

Applied the sizeof() fix. We definitely shouldn't be doing that in a loop.

Same problem exists in the walk() function on line 513.

item.title: link-template.php-2.diff attached to Ticket #6999
item.dc:creator: JohnLamansky
item.description: A less-convoluted way of allowing attributes; use this instead.

item.title: Ticket #7149 (prevent inadvertent output from included files) created
item.dc:creator: mm6
item.description:
A couple days ago I accidentally broke all my feeds and XMLRPC by introducing a newline in my theme's functions.php file. This caused a newline before the xml declaration in the generated XML which breaks XML parsers.

It got me thinking if there was a way to ignore the output from an included file that should never generate any output. What if the include was wrapped in this? 

ob_start()
include(STYLESHEETPATH . '/functions.php');
ob_end_clean()

If anyone thinks is a good idea I can make a patch.

item.title: Ticket #7112 (Add Icons to the Design - Widgets Page in the Admin Panel) updated
item.dc:creator: strider72
item.description:
I'm for this with two caveats:

1) I agree that it should be a CSS background. This is purely visual, and not needed in the HTML.

2) I believe the code that allows plugins to add widgets should also be changed so custom widgets can have included icon images as well.

item.title: Ticket #7148 (Issues with changing color of highlighted text and selecting other ...) created
item.dc:creator: bubel
item.description:
Highlight a paragraph or so of text in the visual editor. Change the text color.

Then, try to highlight another group of text (i.e. the next paragraph), and the focus will continue reverting to the last paragraph that you highlighted (and successfully changed the color of). Essentially, the text that you previously highlighted will not lose focus. This prohibits user from selecting anything else in the editor.

Saving the post seems to remedy the issue.

Reproduced in IE7.

Revision: 8112

item.title: Ticket #7147 (Problems with 700+ categories) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: The exact same query was being run for the dropdown and the table. This is because one had hierarchial set to true and the other set it to 1. Lame. We need to make the cache keying more robust. Worked around it for now by making both use true.

item.title: Ticket #7147 (Problems with 700+ categories) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: (In [8112]) Make the args for the category drop down query the same as the category table query so that the cache is used. Eliminates a query. see #7147

item.title: Ticket #7147 (Problems with 700+ categories) updated
item.dc:creator: DD32
item.description:
Passing $terms by ref to _get_term_children() looks like it would cause a Call-time pass-by-reference

Ah... The slight time decrease that that added was probably because it skipped over a few terms here and there.

categories.php is paged in 2.6, which helps a lot.

Hepls a lot, But still has a huge performance hit on the page mainly because the Add Category parent still has to list them all. It does help if you just want to access a category though.

item.title: Ticket #7147 (Problems with 700+ categories) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: By the way, categories.php is paged in 2.6, which helps a lot. Testing on a blog with 15k categories reduced the time to load categories.php from many minutes to about 8 seconds. Printing 20 categories per page is much faster than printing 15k. :-)

item.title: Ticket #7147 (Problems with 700+ categories) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description:
Applied the sizeof() fix. We definitely shouldn't be doing that in a loop.

Passing $terms by ref to _get_term_children() looks like it would cause a Call-time pass-by-reference warning since the functions declaration wasn't changed to accept pass by ref. Also, an array passed by ref keeps it internal array pointer. Recursive calls to _get_term_children() would be advancing the pointer on the same copy of the terms array, thus the location of where the calling function left off would be lost. Using for() instead of foreach() can get around this.

item.title: Ticket #7147 (Problems with 700+ categories) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: (In [8111]) Don't do sizeof() in a loop. Props DD32. see #7147

item.description: Don't do sizeof() in a loop. Props DD32. see #7147

item.title: 7147.diff attached to Ticket #7147
item.dc:creator: DD32

item.title: Ticket #7147 (Problems with 700+ categories) updated
item.dc:creator: DD32
item.description:
I'd say the main reason for the massive ammount of time is the fact your web server is slower than my local machine.

I noticed sizeof() was being called 200,000 times.. I've made some modifications which has pulled wp_list_categories() down from 36 seconds to 18 seconds. modifying _get_term_children() pulled off another 0.5seconds (I suspect that was just the pass-by-reference call)

item.title: Ticket #7147 (Problems with 700+ categories) updated
item.dc:creator: bi0xid
item.description:
I have 2000 categories with 1020 posts (multi-categories to show a tree with the information).

When showing categories.php, for example, or index.php, which has wp_list_categories(), the page charges more than 692KB, stucking 50 secs later. Walker doesn't work properly with my system.

Apache/1.3.39 (Unix) mod_python/2.7.11 Python/2.4.4 mod_perl/1.29 PHP/5.2.6 MySQL/4.1.22

Is there any problem reported with this versions?

item.title: Ticket #7147 (Problems with 700+ categories) updated
item.dc:creator: DD32
item.description:
Milestone changed

You have closed the ticket because #6561 exists. But it talks about pages, not categories.

oops, Sorry, Mind hadnt fully woken up; I confused the Posts ticket with the closed category ticket.

On my local system, I just setup 1000 categories, and assigned them all to a post. It does indeed take about 10 seconds to show the entire tree.

There are a total of 2 queries made which used 60ms total.

Using the PHP Trace logs, i've come up with this: 

wp_widget_categories: self: 3052ms; total: 6529ms
  wp_list_categories: self: 0.5ms; total: 3477ms
    get_categories: total: 2265ms
      get_terms: total:1205ms
         _get_term_children: 1179ms and calls itself a few thousand times each taking 0.2~30ms which adds up to the 1179ms
    walk_category_tree: total: 2256ms
      Walker::walk 2265ms
        Walker::display_element 0.1~60ms called

Looking at the functions called: 

Walker:display_element
Average: 3.8ms
Total time: 3840ms
Calls: 1019
get_category_link
Average: 0.4ms
Total time: 471ms
Calls: 2009
Walker::start_el
Average: 0.4ms
Total time: 380ms
Calls: 1000

It seems that quite a lot of the time is simple Walker::display_element taking 10+ms on some items.

item.title: Ticket #7147 (Problems with 700+ categories) reopened
item.dc:creator: bi0xid
item.description:
I cannot categorize tags like a tree.

You have closed the ticket because #6561 exists. But it talks about pages, not categories.

I'm going to reopen it, they are not the same.

item.title: Ticket #7147 (Problems with 700+ categories) updated
item.dc:creator: bi0xid
item.description:
It seems the problem is in class Walker_Category.

When using it in wp_list_categories, it gets the database rows one by one. It's more than 2000 queries in my system!

I must use another way to categorize information instead of categories. Any ideas?

item.title: Ticket #6813 (Press This bookmarklet - quick posting from around the web) updated
item.dc:creator: noel
item.description:
Owner changed

Updates are now going in this ticket.

The latest patch fixes problems with paragraphs being transmitted through instead of just line breaks.

I've also attached the loading-publish.gif.

There is still a problem displaying apostrophes despite coming through clean. (?)

Example. Select "it's" in a webpage, click Press This, you'll now get "it\'s". Publish that post and you'll then get "it's" as you should. Anyone? Bueller?

item.title: Ticket #7145 (Link 'Web Address' field strips pipes) created
item.dc:creator: Jairus
item.description:
When creating a new (or editing an existing) link, all pipes will be stripped from the Web Address field (but not Name or Description).

Thus, it's impossible to use Links to link to any sites which use pipes in their URL structure, such as:

​http://www.hallmark.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/category3|10001|10051|181568|147551;-102001;181568|ecards|Just%20Because

item.title: Ticket #7118 (New media uploader uploads files to the wp-admin directory.) updated
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description:
Somehow, their ABSPATH variable is not getting included in the path returned by wp_upload_dir.

See this forum thread for details: ​http://wordpress.org/support/topic/182297

item.title: page-encoded-urls.diff attached to Ticket #6723
item.dc:creator: nbachiyski

item.title: Ticket #6723 (get_page_uri returns invalid URLs for multibyte page slug) updated
item.dc:creator: nbachiyski
item.description:
The urldecode calls were introduced long ago in [1841] (1.3-alpha-4) when for some reason page names were double encoded.

The patch is attached.

item.title: Ticket #6510 ([2.5] wp_list_pages "exclude" arg no longer works as advertised) updated
item.dc:creator: jamescollins
item.description:
Replying to hailin:

This issue is caused by a statement ($rhierarchical? = 0) in post-template.php.

I believe Ryan put there because he wanted to improve the performance of page listing.

post-template.php

Query pages. $rhierarchical? = 0; <== caused the issue !! $pages = get_pages($r);

I can confirm that commenting out this line fixes the problem. This change was made in ticket #5458 (revision [6399]).

Replying to markjaquith:

Assigning to Matt, as this requires an API change.

I'm assigning this back to Matt, as the ball is back in his court. I've done the PHP end -- we now need a change to the server API.
